coredata.dc:title: Amplitudes and phase shifts in electron—atom forward scattering: strong dependence on atomic valence electrons
coredata.dc:creator: Zheng, Y.
Hussain, Z.
Shirley, D.A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts for intermediate-energy electrons were systematically calculated for selected elements throughout the periodic table. Characteristic variations in the forward-scattering amplitudes with atomic number were found, which differ from those observed in back-scattering amplitudes. Strong effects of atomic valence electrons on the forward-scattering process are evident.

Characteristic variations in the forward-scattering amplitudes with atomic number were found, which differ from those observed in back-scattering amplitudes. Strong effects of atomic valence electrons on the forwardscattering process are evident. 1. Introduction Electron-atom scattering in the intermediate-energy range forms the basis of several structural determination techniques, such as extended X-ray-absorption fine structure (EXAFS) [1,2] and its surface counterpart (SEXAFS) [ 3-5 ] low-energy electron diffraction (LEED) [6,7], photoelectron diffraction [8-10], photoelectron and Auger electron forward scattering [11-13], and electron holography [ 14-17 ] . In the intermediate-energy range, electron-atom scattering is largely dominated by the back and forward scattering of electrons by atoms. A full understanding of these two scattering processes is therefore important in the applications of these techniques. Back scattering of electrons by atoms in the intermediate-energy range has been studied previously in detail because of its direct applications in the use of EXAFS and SEXAFS for bulk and surface structural determinations. In particular, the back-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts which describe the basic characteristics of the back-scattering process have been systematically calculated for a large number of elements in the periodic table in this energy range [ 18-20]. It has become accepted that the back scattering of electrons by atoms in this energy range is largely dominated by the atomic core potential. The importance of the forward scattering of electrons by 108 atoms in applications of the above techniques has also been realized [ 21,22 ] and extensive studies have been done on the physics underlying the forwardscattering process in the intermediate-energy range [ 13 ]. There is now a general understanding that, as in the back-scattering, the forward scattering of electrons by atoms in this energy range is also largely dominated by the atomic core potential. However, no systematic study of forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts has been carried out for this energy range. In this work, forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts in the intermediate-energy range (which we shall take as k-5-10 A-') were systematically calculated for several elements throughout the periodic table. Characteristic variations in the forwardscattering amplitudes with atomic number have been found, which differ from those observed in the backscattering amplitudes. Strong effects of atomic valence electrons on the forward-scattering process are therefore proposed. It is noted that these effects are of interest in connection with structural determination methods which depend on electron-atom forward scattering. 2. In the muffin-tin potential approximation, the partial wave phase shifts were calculated using a modified version of Pendry's program [ 6 ] with Herman-Skillman wavefunctions. The atomic electronic wavefunctions were truncated at the muffintin sphere radius, which was usually chosen as 1.5 times the atomic covalent radius, and the charge associated with the atomic electronic wavefunctions which extend beyond the muffin-tin sphere radius was simply added uniformly back into the muffin-tin sphere. In calculating the plane-wave forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts, up to 25 partial wave phase shifts were summed to achieve convergence in both the total forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts through the intermediate-energy range. 3. Results and discussion Fig. 1 a shows the calculated forward-scattering amplitudes through the intermediate-energy range for elements in two major columns of the periodic table: group IV and group VII. The calculated forwardscattering amplitudes for elements in these columns tend to increase with increasing electron wave vector k through this energy range. Furthermore, fig. 1 a shows that the calculated forward-scattering amplitudes of elements in each column generally tend to increase with increasing atomic number. There are exceptions to both trends. It is usually understood [ 13 ] that the forward scattering of electrons by atoms is largely dominated by the atomic core potential. The above trends observed in the forward-scattering amplitudes can be understood along this line: with increasing the electron wave vector (kinetic energy), the electrons come closer to the atomic cores and the screening effects of the atomic valence electrons on the atomic core AMPLITUDE 4 AMPLITUDE i~ A1 ___ Fig. 1. Fig. lb shows the calculated forward-scattering amplitudes in the intermediate-energy range for elements in four major rows of the periodic table. The figure shows that the calculated forward-scattering amplitudes of these elements also generally increase with increasing k in this energy range. However, the calculated forward-scattering amplitudes of the elements in this energy range always decrease with increasing atomic number within each row, and change from one row to another. This trend in the forwardscattering amplitudes with atomic number in the higher k region differs from that of the corresponding back-scattering amplitudes, which show varying behavior throughout the k range but generally increase with atomic number in the higher k region. We infer that the forward scattering of electrons by atoms in the intermediate-energy range is not entirely dominated by the atomic core potentials. Figs. 2a and 2b show the calculated atomic potentials for elements in one column and one row in the periodic table. It can be seen from fig. 2a that, with increasing atomic number in column VII, the strengths of the atomic potential in both the core and outer regions increase. This result can explain the increasing forward-scattering amplitudes for the same atoms. On the other hand, fig. 2b shows that, with increasing atomic number along a row, the strength of the atomic potential in the core region (r < 0.3 A ) increases, but it decreases in the outer region (r> 0.5 A), because of screening effects from the atomic valence electrons. The decreasing trend in the atomic potentials at larger with atomic number within a row matches that of the corresponding forward-scattering amplitudes. We propose as an explanation that the forward-scattering of electrons by atoms is strongly affected by screening due to atomic valence electrons. On this particular point, there is a big difference between the back- and forward-scattering processes: small impact parameters are required for the back-scattering of electrons by atoms in this energy range, so that the back-scattering process is dominated by the atomic core potentials. In fact, there are several differences in characteristics between back- and forward-scattering amplitudes. For example, unlike the back-scattering amplitudes, there are no peaks and valleys in the forward-scattering amplitudes. Figs. 3a and 3b show the calculated forward-scattering phase shifts in the intermediate-energy range for elements in two major columns and three major rows in the periodic table. First, at the higher k region in this energy range, the forward-scattering phase shifts of all elements generally decrease with increasing k and increase with increasing atomic number in each column and each row. Secondly, in the whole energy range, the forward-scattering phase shifts of the elements of low atomic number decrease monotonically with increasing k and their k slopes remain nearly unchanged with increasing atomic number. Note that in all cases the k slopes of the forward-scattering phase shifts are much smaller than those of the corresponding back-scattering phase shifts. We note that similar results have been obtained for the forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts in the intermediate-energy range when the partial wave phase shifts are calculated using Rehr's program [20]. In summary, the forward-scattering amplitudes and phase shifts in the intermediate-energy range have been systematically calculated for several elements in the periodic table. Characteristic variations in the forward-scattering amplitudes as a function of atomic number have been found. We propose that the forward-scattering of electrons by atoms in the intermediate-energy range is strongly affected not only by the atomic cores but also by the atomic valence electrons. This result has important implications for the methods which make use of forward-scattering phenomena in surface structural determinations. Acknowledgement YZ would like to thank Dr. A.G.
